Comment: N.B. The root would appear to be **ba- with various extensions in both families
N.B. The root would appear to be **bi-, cf. pP *b̄ii 'mosquito', pT *bia 'louse'
N.B.perhaps an example of sound symbolism

Concept: stone in form of an axe

Comment: probably for all three persons singular
apparently used for only 1st and 2nd persons
Found only in Ese and War. The Čamic forms, if not loans from the Panoan, would apper to come from a pT *uze/u

The form in Takana is mueta which is the reflex generally of a hypothetical *maeta. In the 1880s Armentia transcribed the Takana word as <maeta>. The irregularity of the Takana form has never been explained: now it is possible to speculate on the metathesis of the initial *ya- found in Panoan.

Shell does not account for such forms in her cognate sets as Isconawa mbɨča ‘wet’, mbɨčaki̹ ‘be wet’, Yaninawa buitšɨdɨ ‘wet’, which point to *b̴ rather than to *m. Also to be found in Shell is pP *mɨwɨ ‘waterhole’. Here again, Isconawa shows mbɨwɨ ‘waterhole’. Abreu’s Cashinawa shows”: bɨa ‘to draw liquid from a vase’, bɨsa ‘fine rain’, bɨca ‘wash outside’, bɨcis ‘to put out fire with water’, and bɨča ‘to wash the face, to wash outside’. It is possible that two roots are present here: *mɨ+ča ‘to wet hands’ and *b̴i+ča ‘to wet the face’. PT *beca ‘to swim’. This Takanan form is to be found under *be3- ‘arm,shoulder’ because Armentia glossed the Takana form beca as ‘breacer, that is, move the arms, brachiate’
generally with a reference to animal as opposed to human body parts, and probably no longer productive
Some sources gloss this word as ‘pinsha, bird sp.’ and the word may therefore be a loan into Pano-Takanan, which may account for its slight irregularity to Takanan.
The Takanan form has some peculiarities: Kav has piya and not the expected piha.

Concept: many compounds with reference to stringlike objects
mapajo,algodón silvestre (a tree sp. With natural wool)

Comment: e.g. pi-bo-na-šina-ka-ʔita-kɨ ‘Yesterday on the way here at night they ate’
The Takanan form is found in both free and bound form, for example, Tak. Hanawa-cine-ke ‘rest all day’

Concept: bone (as a second member of a compound)
bone (as a second member of a compound)
bone (as a second member of a compound)
Comment: cf. pT *ba(i)-c̣u ‘elbow’. The etymology of Tak. *-c̣u however may be related to *c̣u1- and not to *c̣au.

Concept: round,bent,and many compounds which have reference to that particular shape

Comment: This is the only correspondance of pP *y and pT *d, despite the fact that pP *y is a fairly common phoneme. These forms may not be original but rather from the Spanish Dios (?)
Both pP and pT forms may, however, be ancient Arawak loans
